The long-distance runner Richard Nerurkar is one of the top 10,000-meter runners in Britain. He visits a high-altitude training camp in Kenya. The camp is located ten miles south of the equator and is surrounded by beautiful playing fields and dense tropical vegetation.
The training camp is basic, but the athletes have everything they need to train. They live in cinder-block dormitories and have three work-outs each day. The daily regime begins at six and includes a leisurely early-morning run, interval training at mid-morning, and a steady run in the late afternoon.
When the day's running is over, the athletes have a simple life. They eat a healthy diet, take a bath in the stream, and relax.
By the time Richard left the camp, he was even more appreciative of Kenyan success. He realized that their success is not due to genetics or upbringing alone. He believes that the purity and simplicity of the mountainside lifestyle, the gruelling work-outs, and the passion for success are the secrets behind Kenya's rise to the top of world distance running.

Advertising is not doing well. It started to decline early in 1989, well before the recession began. The main reason for the decline is that advertising has not been able to keep up with the pace of economic change.
Most people do not buy most of the brands they see advertised. Waste is inherent in the use of media for advertising. However, advertising can still be cost-effective. If an advertiser can target the right audience, they can be successful.

Solar Survivor Charles Clover visited a very environmentally-friendly home in Britain called Southwell in Nottinghamshire. The house is full of surprises. It has a beautiful ancient cathedral called Southwell Minster and a greenest dwelling designed and built by Robert and Brenda Vale. The Vales use rainwater for washing and drinking, recycle their sewage into garden compost and heat their house with waste heat from electrical appliances and their own body heat.
The house is super-insulated with krypton-filled triple-glazed windows. It is also very quiet. You can hear no sound inside. Once you are inside and with your shoes off, there is a monastic stillness. The Vales designed the house to be low-tech and there is little to go wrong. It was cheap to build and cost the same price per square metre as low-cost housing for rent.

The camera can lie. Arthur Conan Doyle, the creator of the Sherlock Holmes stories, believed himself to be a rational man and a scientist. In 1920, he saw photographs of fairies taken in a garden setting and thought that these tiny creatures really existed. He published the photographs alongside an article he wrote, acknowledging fairies as supernatural wonders. It was not until 1939 that the two ladies who took the photos admitted that these were fake. They simply cut out pictures of fairies from a book and arranged them among flowers. The results are undeniably beautiful. But the simplicity of the trick undermines a basic principle of photography, that the camera cannot lie. But it can, and always could. Today, we are used to computer software enabling us to rework our digital images and it is a myth that photography ever had a true age of innocence. From the moment cameras began capturing reality, that reality was being altered.

Blacksmiths have been working with iron for many years. They have made weapons, armour, and farming tools. They have also been praised for their artistry. In the past, blacksmiths were very important people. They were like doctors and astrologers. But over time, the number of blacksmiths decreased. This was because heavy industry no longer needed them. However, there has been a recent revival of blacksmithing. This is due to greater interest in decorative architecture and a less conservative approach to interior design.
There are many different types of blacksmithing. Some blacksmiths make gates and balconies. Others make bookends and sculptures. Still others make jewelry and tools. No other metal can give man as much visual pleasure or a greater feeling of security. The chances of iron being used decoratively for the next thousand years are good.

I stopped smoking a few months ago. It was a difficult decision, but I knew I had to do it. I had been smoking for many years and I was addicted. I had tried to quit before, but I had always failed. This time, I was determined to succeed.
The stop-smoking session was a group therapy and hypnotherapy session. It took place two months and three weeks ago. I did not intend to stop smoking, but I was persuaded to try. I was told to smoke as much as I wanted, but I found that I was not able to smoke as much as I thought I would.
I am glad that I stopped smoking. I have not regretted it. I have more energy and I am able to concentrate better. I also have a healthier family. I am still coming to the view that smoking had a great deal to do with displacing boredom. However, I am not perfect. I still smoke sometimes, but I am working hard to quit.

Dorothy Hodgkin was a British scientist who won the Nobel prize in chemistry in 1964 for her work on penicillin and vitamin B12. She was also the first woman to win a Nobel prize.
Hodgkin's life was full of accomplishments and challenges. She had three children and was married to a historian. She was also devoted to her scientific work.
Scientific inquiry was Hodgkin's passion. She pushed the technique into realms of complexity others deemed unreachable at the time. Her work on penicillin and vitamin B12 was very important. It helped to save many people's lives.

Margaret Wilkins has a special ability to find water. She can hold a forked hazel stick above the ground and detect water. She is very busy these days because there has been a lot of drought. Most of her customers are farmers whose wells have dried up. To find water, Margaret uses a map and a hazel stick. She also checks the land with her hazel stick. If she finds water, she drills a well. The water that she finds is clean and running in fissures of impervious rock. However, there are some challenges to finding water. One challenge is the cost of electricity to run the pump. Another challenge is the risk of farm waste getting into the water supply. But Margaret is still able to find water for her customers. She is a very successful businesswoman.

We changed lives for a day! Have you ever dreamed of swapping lives with someone else for a day? It would be more fun to do something quite different for a change. We fixed it for four people - read how it went.
Amanda, a young mother, swapped lives with her friend Cindy, who works as a waitress at a restaurant. Amanda had a busy day taking care of her two daughters. Cindy had a busy day waitressing and taking care of the children.
Rosemary, who runs a dairy farm, swapped lives with Hilary, a teacher. Rosemary had a busy day milking cows and making ice-cream. Hilary had a busy day teaching children and inspecting sheep.
D. Hilary's story I arrived at the farm at 8.30 am, bright and early, only to discover that Rosemary had been up for hours. The process of milking cows and making ice-cream is very tiring. I found it quite a lonely day.

A trumpet is not just for Christmas. It is strange that many musicians, even leading ones, come from homes without music. Hakan Hardenberger is a musician who has established himself as unique among the world's trumpet-players today. He was born in southern Sweden and has a unique talent for playing the trumpet. His records are continually opening up new repertory, not just concertos by long-neglected composers, but new works too.
Hardenberger was born near Malmo and owes his career to the accident of a Christmas present when he was only eight. His father had the idea of giving his only son a trumpet. The success of the gift was instant. The boy never stopped playing. He had a natural talent for playing the trumpet and was taught by Bo Nilsson, a second trumpet-player in the Malmo Symphony Orchestra.
Hardenberger has a unique gift of communicating through his music. He is able to make people feel happy and sad, excited and relaxed. He is a true artist and his music is always moving.

New In Paperback A is a story about a fictional republic called Efica and its inhabitants. The book is notable for its humour, unique vision, and penetrating psychological insight. It also includes a character named Harriet who is middle-class and has her own business. One day, her son Joe is attacked in the street by a teenager named Leo. After the court case, both boys refuse to talk about what happened. Leo had been a model pupil and had never been involved in a fight before, while Joe recovers physically but becomes withdrawn. Harriet is tortured by the effect on her son and ministering to him takes over her life.
The book also includes a character named Sheila who is working-class and looks after her ageing father. She is so wracked with guilt that she requests a meeting - from which their unusual friendship grows. The author is skilled at depicting how people react to upheaval in their lives and he also captures the mothers sense that, no matter how hard she tries, she can never do enough.

Take Five Careers Rebecca Cripps meets five women who talk about their different professions. Each woman has her own unique job and challenges.
A. The Brain Surgeon
Anne is a brain surgeon. She operates on patients all Monday and Wednesday, as well as some Friday afternoons. She has to work long hours and sometimes worries about what she's going to do the next day.
B. The Senior Designer
Marita is a senior designer. She spends a lot of time managing people and working on projects. She has to deal with deadlines and keep up with a lot of work.
C. The Chauffeur
Linda is a chauffeur. She has to be careful not to get tired and has to deal with rude passengers.
D. The Landscape Gardener
Tracy is a landscape gardener. She spends a lot of time working outdoors and has to deal with the weather.
E. The Civil Engineer
Zena is a civil engineer. She works on building bridges and retaining walls. She has to deal with a lot of paperwork and find solutions to problems.

Six people talk about their typical working day.
A. Credit Card Executive
I wake up early and arrive at the office early to manage all the customer development programmes for our regular credit card users. I have to keep in touch with existing card users, acquire new ones and build relationships with partner companies. I have a lot of meetings and I also deal with a lot of e-mail messages.
B. Record Company Executive
I get to work late and listen to demo tapes. I try to be constructive and instinctively know if the sound is appropriate for our record label. I start on the first album and oversee budgets and spending. I also go to gigs and socialise a lot.
C. Sales Director
I wake up early and drive to work to open the post and check if we're going to see any clients that day. I love taking people round the showrooms and reaching agreements with clients. I sell antiques and buy from various sources. I do the accounts and tax returns and leave work early.
D. Air Traffic Controller
I work a set shift pattern and control aircraft movements. It's important to be really switched on and be able to handle stressful situations. I find the work quite stressful and it can take a while to wind down at the end of a shift.
E. Shop Manager
I get to work early and help customers. I also spend time discussing new titles with publishers' reps. I have to consider how many, if any, of a particular title the shop is likely to sell. I do a late shift and close down the computer system.
F. Financial Analyst
I listen to the news and assess financial risk for multi-national companies operating abroad. I provide three services and travel to Africa about three times a year. I leave work early.

Career Power Get the leading edge - motivate yourself to take full control at work. To be a good leader, you need to inspire, be an agent of change, and develop others. It's not about being tall or intelligent. To convey enthusiasm and encourage it in others, a good leader should be able to speak clearly and with conviction. You also need to be able to set goals and achieve them. To become a leader, you need to recognise your latent talents, develop them, and use them. You can benefit from improving your leadership skills, regardless of your position. To be a successful leader, you need to be able to delegate, motivate, organise, and chastise effectively. You also need to be visible and accessible to those who are important. But remember, you don't have to lead all the time.

The movie "A Abyss Long Before Titanic" is a Cold War thriller about oil riggers and navy experts trying to rescue a nuclear submarine stranded deep underwater. The movie has impressive production design and special effects, but the dialogue and characterization are not as strong.
The movie "The Thin Red Line" is a war movie about the battle for Guadalcanal. It is a conventional war movie, but it has some interesting moments. The flashback sequence, in which the soldier dreams of his wife, is handled with a harshness which arguably works better than Malick's soft-focus imagery of the woman on the swing.
The movie "On Guard" is a swashbuckler adventure film. It is corny but highly watchable. The film has a consummate villain and an exuberant hero.
The movie "Character" is a dark and vicious parable set in turn-of-the-century Rotterdam. The film has excessive production and costume design, but the storytelling is not as strong as the visuals.
The movie "The Good, the Bad and the Ugly" is a digitally re-mastered war epic. The sound editing is impressive, but the storytelling is relentless and cruel.

Steve Martin's book, "Compelling Evidence," is a compelling read. The narrator, a lawyer, finds himself defending his boss's wife when she is tried for her husband's murder. The trial scenes are exciting and the book has a surprising twist at the end.
Sigmundondo, a charismatic troubleshooter, is the protagonist of "Curtains for the Cardinal." The plot is complex and the book is long, but it is still a great read.
Sarah Lacey, a tax inspector, is the detective in "File Under: Deceased." She is a gutsy and versatile detective who is able to solve the case despite facing challenges.
"Double Deuce" by Robert B. Parker is a high-quality detective novel. Spenser, a private investigator, assists his friend Hawk in clearing drug dealers out of a deprived estate.
Faye Kellermann's book, "False Prophet," is an entertaining mystery. The author's easy writing style and eye for odd human behaviour make this book a pleasure to read.

I'm 34 years old and I'm nervous about backpacking. I quit my job and rented out my flat to go travelling in South East Asia for a year. I'm excited about this trip, but I'm also worried about making the necessary arrangements and organizing everything. I'm also concerned about feeling out of place among a community of backpackers fresh out of school and university.
There are a lot of reasons why people are backpacking in their late twenties and thirties. Some people want to disentangle themselves from the lives they've made for themselves and head off to foreign climes. Others want to have a final fling before settling down. And still others want to take a break from their jobs and reassess their lives.
I'm not sure if I'm running away or running towards something, but I'm definitely excited about this trip. I'm going to take the time to enjoy myself and see what happens.

I was feeling out of touch with the changes brought about by technology because I had taken a long break from journalism. I decided to transform the family home into an efficient workplace. I won a computer package and set up a mini-office in a corner of the kitchen. I have everything I need to work from home, including a computer, a modem, and a telephone-answering facility. I also have a lot of new opportunities to write articles for a magazine. I am grateful for the computer because it has made me more organized and efficient. It has also made it easier to research stories and connect with people from all over the world.

The Tartan Museum is a modern museum in Scotland. It has a lot of interesting objects. The museum is located in Edinburgh, a historic city. The museum building is very impressive. It has a huge, yellow sandstone tower and cheese-wedge buildings.
The museum has a lot of exhibitions. There are stories about the history of Scotland. There are also stories about the people who lived in Scotland. The museum has a lot of beautiful objects. There are jewels, silver, and paintings.
The museum also has a Discovery Centre. It is a place where children can learn about the history of Scotland. The Discovery Centre has a lot of interactive games and activities.
Overall, the Tartan Museum is a very interesting museum. It is a must-see for anyone who is visiting Scotland.

The end of print may take some time. It's a calming concept. Change can be frightening and challenging, but it also means going from somewhere to somewhere else. Newspapers are facing a decline in sales, but their websites are growing. The decline in print sales is happening in the West, but Asia is making up the difference. Books are also changing. Kindle and similar e-readers are booming, but booksellers found that sales of physical books have only decreased slightly. There are a lot of different trends happening in different countries. In Britain, sales have dropped by 10.8%, but in Germany, the decline is only 7%. And in France, the fall is only 3.1%. These trends reflect a situation that is more complicated than people think. Newspapers have to find a way to attract a paying readership. They are using paywalls and joint packages to do this. However, it is difficult and expensive to maintain both an active website and an active print edition.

People are the most interesting subjects to photograph. A photograph with someone in it is usually more compelling than the same shot without the human interest. To photograph people well, you need to be aware of actions, gestures and expressions. You also need to be mindful of the presence of the camera.
When photographing groups of people, avoid straight lines and arrange people at different angles and distances. For posing individuals, help them relax and find a comfortable position. To make a picture more engaging, consider eye contact, expressions and gestures. You can also use the background to add interest and information about the subject.
If you are photographing two or more people interacting, look for opportunities to capture the interaction between them. You can also photograph people against a relevant background. To show people against a background, use a standard or wide-angle lens and move far enough back to get the whole building or mountain in the frame.
A good picture will show a balance between the subjects and the place they were visiting. To capture a good picture, consider the following tips: avoid straight lines, arrange people at different angles and distances, help them relax and find a comfortable position, consider eye contact, expressions and gestures, use the background to add interest and information, and capture the interaction between subjects.

Sarah Janson is an artist who creates illusions of reality through her paintings. She is not interested in being known as the artist who created the work, but rather the artist who made the work. Janson has been painting trompe-l'oeil for sixteen years and has a string of major corporate and private commissions behind her. Much of her work is inspired by architecture or made for architectural settings.
When Janson finishes a painting, she often feels that she has not done it justice. She is also brutally honest about her 'failings' and is frank about her mathematical abilities. Despite her inclination to play down her talent, Janson is constantly busy. She is generous in praise of her clients and is always willing to listen to their ideas.

In today's workplace, emotional intelligence (EQ) is more important than ever before. It is the ability to understand and manage your own emotions and the emotions of others. EQ includes basic elements such as self-awareness, self-regulation, motivation, empathy, and social adeptness.
If you have high EQ, you are more likely to be successful in your job. You are also more likely to be able to work well with others. In fact, studies have shown that people who have high EQ are more likely to be promoted and earn higher salaries.
There are many ways to improve your EQ. You can learn about EQ and practice the skills that are involved. You can also seek professional help if you need it.
In conclusion, emotional intelligence is a valuable asset in the workplace. It can help you to be more successful, happier, and more productive.

The media can earn money from content they don't own. Social media has made it easier to share news and pictures. Sometimes, journalists use pictures from social media to report on events. Unfortunately, some reporters have published pictures that were not theirs. There is a debate about whether it is ethical to use pictures from social media without permission. Many people film or photograph news events. This means that UGC has a big part to play in the future of the media. To keep the public's trust, the media needs to take steps to ensure that people are properly rewarded for their work and that permission is always sought.

Ancient Chinese medicine, also known as acupuncture, is a traditional Chinese system of medicine that has been used for centuries. It is used to treat many different conditions, but acupuncture's role in treating pain has been the most popular.
Acupuncture involves inserting fine needles into the skin at specific points on the body. These points are related to meridians, which are lines of energy that flow through the body. When the flow of energy is disrupted, the body becomes unbalanced and can become sick.
Acupuncturists use a variety of techniques to find out where the imbalances occur in the energy flow. They may examine your tongue, feel your pulses on your wrist, or assess your general appearance. Once they have found the imbalances, they will use needles to stimulate the flow of energy.
Acupuncture can be effective for treating a variety of pain conditions, including back pain, arthritis, headaches, and migraines. It is also sometimes used to treat other conditions, such as menstrual pain and facial nerve pain.
If you are considering trying acupuncture, it is important to find a qualified acupuncturist. You should also discuss your health concerns with your doctor before making any decisions.

P.D. James, a best-selling crime writer, is known for her complex and brilliant imagination. She exudes an air of quiet authority, but it is soon apparent that she is actually shy. She has written 12 major detective novels that are read avidly by millions all over the world.
P.D. James was born in Oxford and grew up mainly in Cambridge. She worked full-time in administration for the National Health Service and made good use of her organizational skills. She also became 'quite accustomed' to seeing corpses while working in forensic science.
Writing detective stories is a way for P.D. James to bring order out of disorder. She believes that the solution of a crime confirms the sanctity of life, even if that life is unlovable.

The pen is more powerful than a psychoanalyst. Handwriting analysis, or graphology, is a science that can reveal a person's character and health. If you apply for a job in some countries, you will probably be asked to write a sample of your handwriting. Your handwriting will be used to determine your suitability for the job.
Graphology can be used to indicate certain illnesses, such as heart disease and cancer, and can reveal psychological states and emotional disturbances. It can also be used for vocational guidance and as an adjunct to interviews. Many big companies now employ graphologists to analyse the handwriting of potential candidates for key jobs.
However, most doctors and psychiatrists remain skeptical about the value of graphology. They say that handwriting is a product of education, artistic ability and the type of writing taught - and has no other significance.

Is your office working ok? Fresh air and comfortable chairs are the key to a happy, healthy workforce, according to a new survey. We went to four different offices to find out how healthy and happy they were as working environments.
In Office A, the team of seven people have created a happy, homely working environment. They adapt to the changing seasons by opening doors and roof panels or switching on electric radiators.
In Office B, the office is comfortable and well-maintained, but it lacks personality. The walls are bare and the environment is impersonal.
In Office C, the office is very busy and has a lot of activity. However, the desks and chairs are not very inspiring.
In Office D, the office is very dusty and uncomfortable. The furniture is old and the space is cluttered.
The survey found that the most important factors for a healthy and happy workforce are fresh air, comfortable chairs, and a positive work environment.

Chewing gum is a popular fashion accessory in the United States, where people chew an average of 12 million sticks a day. Gum is made from a natural substance called chicle, which is obtained from the sapodilla tree. In the past, people chewed gum made from the bark of trees or from a resin obtained from the mastic tree. Today, most gum is made synthetically. It contains fewer than ten calories per stick, but it is classified as a food and must therefore conform to the standards of the American Food and Drug Administration. Gum manufacturers say that chewing gum can help reduce tooth decay. They say that chewing gum can increase your salivary flow and help neutralize plaque acid.

The Ghanerao Hotel in India and the Hermitage Hotel in New Zealand are two charming hotels that offer a peaceful escape from the hustle and bustle of city life. The Ghanerao Hotel is located in a small rural village dominated by craftsmen, while the Hermitage Hotel is situated amidst breathtaking scenery on a glacier. Both hotels provide basic facilities, but their unique charm and tranquil atmosphere make them popular among travelers.
The Paradis Hotel on Mauritius is another tranquil retreat. Surrounded by a private beach and lush greenery, this hotel offers a serene escape for those seeking a quiet getaway. The Ladera Hotel in St. Lucia is known for its dramatic setting and colonial style. Its open rooms offer stunning views of the Pitons and the Caribbean Sea.
The Splendid Hotel in Istanbul is a historic gem that exudes a charming atmosphere. Its unique architecture and cozy rooms make it a perfect place to relax and unwind. The Chateau d'Etoges in France is a beautiful seventeenth-century chateau that offers a unique blend of history and luxury. The Fairview Hotel in Kenya is a comfortable and affordable option for travelers seeking a peaceful retreat.
The Hotel Splendido in Italy is steeped in history and offers a glimpse into the glamorous world of the past. Its elegant atmosphere and impeccable service make it a sought-after destination for celebrities and discerning travelers alike.

The hotel inspector, Sue Brown, judges hotels for a living. One day, she was inspecting the Globe Hotel. Things were not going well from the beginning. The receptionist was not aware of the guest she was ignoring. Sue was not happy with the service. She said, "Very poor." It was a classic arrival-phase error. Sue has encountered this many times before. However, the hotel is still rated among the top 130 of the 4,000 listed in the hotel guide. There was a problem with the access to the hotel and the room. The room was stuffy and had a large hole in the wall. Sue was tough and she made her opinions known. She suggested that the hotel manager fix the problems and not usher guests into the room so readily. The manager agreed to listen to her suggestions. He was grateful that Sue was not going to recommend that the hotel be stripped of its red stars.

Seven Up Mountaineer Doug Scott shares his experience of conquering the highest peak on each continent, the Seven Summits. My quest to climb the Seven Summits came late in life. I climbed the Seven Summits in the order I completed them.
A. Mt. Everest, Asia (8,848m)
I climbed Mt. Everest with my climbing partner, Dougal Haston. We were in a snow cave below the summit when I started talking to my feet. The cold was getting into my feet and I recalled other climbers who had lost fingers and toes from frostbite.
B. Mt. McKinley, North America (6,194m)
I climbed Mt. McKinley with Dougal Hatton. The air pressure in the polar regions is lower than at sea level, which has an impact on the body out of all proportion to its altitude. We packed our bags and finally staggered onto the summit and down the other side, triumphant.
C. Kilimanjaro, Africa (5,89Sm)
I climbed Kilimanjaro with Paul Braithwaite. We got lost in the dense jungles of the lower slopes and ran out of water. We spent the third night on a windswept ridge; by now we were both suffering.
D. Aconcagua, South America (6,960m)
I climbed Aconcagua with my wife, Sharu. We decided to miss out on the glacier and go across the north ridges instead. The wind was strong as we walked the last few metres to the summit.
E. Vinson Massif, Antarctica (4,897m)
I climbed Vinson Massif with a team. We all got to the top within 8 hours, but the visibility was down to just a few metres in the storm.
F. Elbrus, Europe (5,633m)
I climbed Elbrus with a team. We crossed open slopes and reached the summit.
G. Carstensz Pyramid, Australasia (4,883m)
I climbed Carstensz Pyramid with a team. We reached the summit by 11 am. I was given a standing ovation on this, my seventh summit. Mission accomplished!

Ned Ingham designs wedding dresses. He says that people should avoid traditional, stiff dresses and frilly looks in favour of simpler styles. He has been drawing and designing wedding dresses since he was a schoolboy.
Sally Quail is a jeweller. She designed her own engagement ring and set up her own business. Her pieces are sought out by many stars of stage and screen.

Peter Little is a hairdresser. He has been styling hair for over 20 years and has a long waiting list.
Penny Pratt is a florist. She has a small shop and provides floral ideas to restaurants and supermarkets. She has also started her own London Flower School.

The Merrion Hotel is a five-star hotel that has recently opened in Dublin. It is a new hotel that has been built using the latest technology. The hotel has a lot of technology that makes it very comfortable and convenient for guests.
The hotel has a computer system that can deal with return clients and store their preferences. It also has a system that controls room temperature. Guests can change the temperature themselves or have it adjusted by the staff. The hotel also has a lot of other amenities, such as a swimming pool, gym, conference rooms, bars, and restaurants.
The Merrion Hotel is a luxurious and well-managed hotel that is likely to be successful.

Artist Susan Shepherd is known for her flower paintings. She has a large garden that is full of her favourite flowers, mostly tulips and poppies. Some of the plants are unruly and seed themselves all over the garden. There is a harmony of colour, shape and structure in the flower borders that line the paved path. Much of this is due to the previous owners who were keen gardeners. They left plants that appealed to Susan. She also inherited the gardener, Danny.
Susan prefers to focus on detailed studies of individual plants rather than on the garden as a whole. She picks them and then takes them up to her studio. She takes one flower out and paints it, which might take a few days. Then, she brings in another flower and builds up the painting that way. Sometimes it takes a couple of years to finish.
Her busiest time of year is spring and early summer, when the tulips are out. The poppies also come out at the same time. She finds it fascinating to see how the flowers change and grow. She has always been interested in plants. She used to collect wild flowers from all around the countryside. Nowadays, the garden owes much to plants that originated in far-off lands.

The Brackham area had a lot of trees that were brought down in a terrible storm in March. The town itself lost two great lime trees from the former market square. The disappearance of such prominent features had changed the appearance of the town centre. Chief Inspector Douglas Pelham, head of the local police force, was not able to notice the change because he was sick. He had been sick with bronchitis and was unable to work. When he finally got well, he realized that the loss of the trees had made a permanent difference to the appearance of his living-room. The house stood in a sizeable garden. The garden had created an impression of privacy. Now, though, the storm had changed his outlook. Previously, the view from the living-room had featured the handsome walnut tree. With the tree gone, the room seemed cruelly bright, its worn furnishings exposed in all their shabbiness.

Living in the valley, we had lived there for a long time. One day, we realized that the hills surrounding our valley could be dangerous. It was the year when the storms came early. The snow started to fall and it was very deep. It blocked our lane and made the path slippery. But the snow and wind were not the biggest problem. The river was the biggest problem. The river was flowing very fast and it was threatening to flood our home. The snow started to melt and the river became even fuller. One day, the dam overflowed and the water surged over the edge of the dam and poured into the stream below. The river was wild and it was rushing towards our cottage. We prayed that the water would stay below its wall and thankfully, it did. We can now enjoy the huge clouds that hang over the valley and be thrilled by the tremendous power which the river possesses. Thanks to this protection, we can feel our home in the valley is still secure and safe.

Film critic Mark Adams has been writing articles about films for a newspaper called The Front Page for the last ten years. It was his first proper job. Before that, he had done some reviewing for other newspapers and magazines. He met Tom Seaton, the first arts editor of The Front Page, who had also written for radio and television. Tom hired Mark, but he was not primarily a journalist. He had a different idea for the team of critics. He thought that a team of critics should take care of the art forms that didn't require specialized knowledge. There would be a weekly lunch at which the team would make their choices from the artistic material that Tom had decided they should cover. It all felt like a dream at that time. It seemed unlikely that a paper could be introduced into a crowded market. It seemed just as likely that a millionaire wanted to help Mark personally, and was pretending to employ him. Mark felt lacking in self-confidence. The first time he saw someone reading the newspaper on the London Underground, he didn't know where to look. Tom's original scheme for a team of critics for the arts never took off. It was a good idea, but they didn't get together as planned. So everything was done by phone. Mark chose film as his area of focus. Without Tom's initial push, they would hardly have come up with the present arrangement.

Why would a schoolgirl want to swim 1500m, cycle 40km and then run 1Okm? Because it's fun. Teenager with a taste for endurance WANTED: Sports-mad training partner for triathlete, preferably female. Chance to work with potential Olympic champion. Should be extremely keen on distance running (regular 15km sessions), distance swimming (addiction to winter training in cold rivers useful) and distance cycling (love of 1OOkm an advantage). Ability to do all three without a rest essential.
The triathlon promises to be one of the most popular Olympic sports. Recently it has drawn huge crowds fascinated (and horrified) by athletes swimming 1500m, cycling 40km, then running 1Okm without stopping. It's great fun, and all worth it in the end.
Melanie entered her first triathlon at 14. 'I won the junior section - but then I was the only junior taking part. It seemed so easy that I was waving at my team-mates as I went round.' Full of confidence, she entered the National Championships, and although she had the second fastest swim and the fastest run, she came nowhere. 'I was following this man and suddenly we came to the sea. We realised then that we had gone wrong. I ended up cycling 20 kilometres too far. I cried all the way through the running.' But she did not give up and is determined that she never will.

I love collecting things. Many people enjoy collecting, and one in three adults does it too. It is a world of passion, envy and enthusiasm. If you want to start collecting, remember one thing: you should only collect things that you love. People have been collecting things since the beginning of time. They collect stones, seashells, flowers, paintings and other things. I have been collecting all my life. I have collected everything from flowers to pottery and paintings. My first collection was of stones picked up in my parents' garden. I was fascinated by these objects. I am not alone in being interested in collecting objects. One in three adults indulges the same passion. There are many reasons why people collect. For me, it's just something I enjoy doing. You do not have to be rich and powerful to start a collection. You can collect items as different as tulip bulbs and china cups. As small objects become a popular collector's item, they begin to rise in price.

My job is to put together temporary exhibitions at the Science Museum. I have to read up about the subject of the exhibition and talk to important people in the area so that I can establish the main themes and aims of the exhibition. I also have to make sure the public can understand the thinking behind the exhibition and plan interactive displays, workshops and theatre.
I teach London taxi drivers how to pass their test. I check the accounts and see what new maps and documents need to be produced. I help students work out the most direct route and give them advice on how to take the test.
I live by the coast and work from home as a marine conservationist. I respond to telephone enquiries, produce educational resources and set up training courses. I also work with schools and study centres and run courses for coastal managers and those involved in making decisions about the fate of the seas.
My job is to publish maps and atlases. I have to make sure that the publishing programme matches market requirements and ensure that we keep stocks of the books that we publish. I also have to deal with a lot of administration.

No title. We always go to Ireland in June. Every year, the four of us have spent the first fortnight of the month at Glencorn Lodge in County Antrim. It's a large house by the sea, not far from the village of Ardbeag. The Malseeds bought the house and have added to it. They have done everything discreetly. We've been playing cards together for ages, Dekko, Strafe, Cynthia and myself. We're all about the same age and live quite close to the town where the Malseeds were before they decided to make the change from England to Ireland.
In the morning, we'd walk along the sands to Ardbeag and have coffee in the hotel there. In the afternoon, we'd drive somewhere. I knew all that because over the years this kind of pattern had developed. Since first we came here, we'd all fallen hopelessly in love with every variation of its remarkable landscape.
